title: One Sixth Grader's Bully? - His Ignorant Bible-Thumping Teacher

comments.text:
One of the things we now know is Darwinians were lying to us when they 
insisted that the genetic matter of apes and humans are 98% identical. 
 
During the last 12 years, there has been a steady flow of scientific 
discoveries informing us that Chimpanzee and human chromosomes are so 
remarkably different that it is inconceivable for the ape genome to evolve 
into the human genome.  For example:
 
In 2010, Nature published a scientific paper entitled "Chimpanzee and human 
Y chromosomes are remarkably divergent in structure and gene content." 
(Nature, by the way, is the most respected peer reviewed scientific journal 
for evolutionary genetics.)
 
The paper was the product of several teams of well-respected geneticists 
all of whom were fervent supporters of "ape to human evolution." 
 
Nonetheless, they found that:
 
The human Y chromosome has twice as many genes as the Chimpanzee Y 
chromosome.  Humans have at least 78 genes and Chimpanzees have only 37.
 
The Y chromosomes of Chimpanzees and humans are radically different in the 
arrangement of their genes. 
 
Both of these facts make it impossible for apes to have evolved into humans 
because there are no genetic mechanisms that would account for the vast 
differences between the ape and human Y chromosomes.
 

 
"Ape to human evolution" theory asserts that the Chimpanzee Y chromosome 
evolved into the human Y chromosome  and few changes were necessary. 
 
That is obviously baloney - there is no way that could have happened.  
 
There is no genetic mechanism that could have rearranged the genes in the 
Chimpanzee Y chromosome to become the human Y chromosome.
 
The two chromosomes are so different it is like comparing the chromosomes 
of humans to those of chickens.
  
APE TO HUMAN EVOLUTION IS IMPOSSIBLE BECAUSE
 
APES AND HUMANS CANNOT ADD GENES TO THEIR GENOMES
 
 
The same research paper also revealed that the human Y chromosome has at 
least 35 more genes than the Chimpanzee Y chromosome.  

 The human Y chromosome has twice as many genes as the Chimpanzee Y 
chromosome.  Humans have 41 more genes.
 
This means that in order for the ape Y chromosome to evolve into the human 
Y chromosome, apes had to add 41 genes.  In order for apes to add genes, 
they would have to have a genetic mechanism to generate new genes and 
insert them into their chromosomes.
 
But apes do not have any "gene generating system."
 
Nor do apes have a "gene insertion system."
 
This means that "ape to human evolution" theory is missing the genetic 
mechanisms necessary for evolution to actually take place.
 
This is ABSOLUTE CONTRADICTING EVIDENCE that proves "ape to human 
evolution" is impossible,﻿
comments.author: Bully380

comments.text:
Darwinians have been dead wrong whenever they have claimed that the 
"genetic matter of ape and humans is 98% identical." The ape and human 
chromosomes are remarkably divergent and too different for "ape to human 
evolution" theory to adequately explain.  For example, the human Y 
chromosome has twice as many genes as the chimpanzee Y chromosome and the 
chromosome structures are not at all similar.
 
Darwin Buster Two: There are laws of embryology that directly contradict 
"ape to human evolution."  One reason is that genes work together in teams 
to form body parts during embryonic development.  This makes it impossible 
to add genes to any genome because there is no way to coordinate any new 
gene with existing genes.  Yet "ape to human evolution" requires apes and 
humans to be able to add genes - for example, the chimpanzee Y chromosome 
has 37 genes and the human Y chromosome has at least 78 genes.
 
Darwin Buster Three: The laws of genetics prevent "ape to human evolution" 
from ever taking place.  One reason is there is no genetic mechanism that 
creates new genes.  But "ape to human evolution" relies on apes and humans 
having the ability to create new genes with new functions.  New genes are 
required in order to have morphological changes, such as gills into lungs 
or more efficient brains.  So called "gene duplication" is not evidence 
that organisms can create new genes.  Although bacteria can duplicate 
existing genes by mistake through "gene duplication," this only occurs in 
single sex bacteria and this is not evidence that apes and humans can 
create new genes with new functions. 
 
Darwin Buster Four:  Darwinians have no explanation for why humans and apes 
have a different number of chromosomes.  Darwinians claim that "chromosome 
fusion" of two ape chromosomes into a single chromosome resulted in humans 
having only 23 pairs of chromosomes while apes have 24 pairs.  But there is 
not one example of "chromosome fusion" in mammals.  Darwinians claim that 1 
in 1000 human babies have a "fused chromosome" but this is an out and out 
lie.  They are actually referring to Robertsonian Translocations, which are 
"translocations" and not fused chromosomes and does not result in a change 
in the chromosome number.  Besides, scientifically derived facts refute 
"chromosome fusion" can occur in apes or humans.﻿

"Monkeys don't turn into humans, for example, but they SHARE a common 
ancestor".  This was said earlier.  Well, there is ABSOLUTELY no empirical 
proof of this.  As a matter of fact, there is no empirical proof of one 
kind turning into another.  Yes, one species has modified or adapted itself 
like the birds in Darwin's Origin of the Species, however there is no 
evidence, definitive evidence, that one kind transformed into, or evolved, 
or became, whatever word you like to use, kind.  Let's me make it clear. 
 For instance, there is NO EVIDENCE, that a cat has evolved into a dog, or 
vice-versa.  There are some great chart that try to predict what the common 
ancestors were, but there is no evidence behind these chart, do your 
homework.  None.  It is completely speculative.  Let's call this 
Macro-Evolution and Micro-Evolution (better titled adaptation). 
 Micro-evolution (Adaption) has scientific merit, Macro-evolution is a 
giant, unsubstantiated leap from Micro-Evolution.  These announcers are 
right, if that is what the teacher said, then the school is ridiculous, 
however Creationism should be taught in the school system, especially since 
evolution is a theory, which, I believe the evidence shows, is a 
three-legged stool.  Creationism is also a theory, with the proof lying in 
the historic truths penned in our heritage.  Which, from a legal 
standpoint, the evidence that Christ was here on earth, died and rose from 
the dead, is hard to dispute.  Read More Than a Carpenter, or Case for 
Faith and you will read some intellectual thinkers in the Christian faith. 
 ﻿

comments.text:
+Macey Johnson Evolution is both theory and fact... as is the theory of 
gravity, or the theory that living things are made of cells (cell theory).

Facts just exist; theories attempt to explain those facts. Facts will not 
cease to exist while theories are in contention -- apples will still fall 
to earth, cells will continue to divide -- whether or not agreement on the 
explantion is reached.

Evolution is confirmed as fact by literally thousands of sources... each 
independent of the others, and each expanding the knowledge and 
understanding of how evolution actually takes place in the real world. It 
is how we understand the fact of viruses becoming more antibiotic-resistant 
over time, for instance.

Science accepts evolution as fact, and there is no argument among 
scientists on the matter.

Creationism is superstition-based religion, nothing else, and is therefore 
and thereby deemed -- by its own abject failure to conform to 
empirically-verifiable factual reality -- to be false.

The 'gift theory of Santa Claus' and the 'stork theory of childbirth' will 
be proven long before any aspect of creationism will ever be proven.

comments.text:
Evolution is not a religion anymore than the law of gravitation is a 
religion. A religion, according to dictionary.com, is, "a set of beliefs 
concerning the cause, nature, and purpose of the universe, especially when 
considered as the creation of a superhuman agency or agencies, usually 
involving devotional and ritual observances, and often containing a moral 
code governing the conduct of human affairs." Evolution is not a set of 
beliefs, it is empirically verified fact. Empirical verification obviously 
does not mean it is 100% true; it can only say it is very, very likely. 
Assuming you are a person who literally interprets the Bible, you believe 
in the Abrahamic God and all of that stuff. It is entirely possible the 
universe was created four seconds ago with our memories implanted by 
malevolent fairies. That is an unfalsifiable claim and does not fall into 
the range of science. You gave yourself some nuance and said that it was 
"in a way" a religion. I believe evolution is true the same way you believe 
that creationism is true. Belief is a belief as long as it is held by a 
conscious creature. The only thing is, as determined by careful observation 
and experiment, which is falsifiable, that evolution is the true belief. 
You have proven to me that your are scientifically illiterate when you say 
that evolution is a theory, by which I mean you tout that fact as if it 
were something tainting evolution. In science there are such things as 
theories and laws. The colloquial definition of theory as you use it, as a 
quasi-hypothesis, is not the scientific definition of theory. I invite you 
to go look that up right now. "Public schools are teaching it as fact when 
it's not which is wrong." The theory of evolution is supported by an 
enormous amount of evidence. Any counter-proposal to explain the diversity 
and origins of life and species have absolutely no reliability or 
veritability as determined by the scientific methods which are awfully good 
at creating theories that accurately explain the natural world. Creationism 
isn't false in the sense that nothing can truly be false. Look up Russel's 
Teapot if you want a lesson on that. You have to weigh the idea that a god 
created the universe 6000 years ago to look like a universe created 
billions of years ago is an unfalsifiable statement. It is POSSIBLE, but 
even a percentage chance can not be given to such a possibility other than 
the fact that is does not fit into the framework of accurate predictive 
theory and evidence we have to reason with. I think we could come to an 
agreement (if you are indeed not a radical skeptic) that schools should not 
teach the idea that the universe was created last Thursday. That is just 
absurd, right? It is the same "amount" of absurd as the idea that the 
universe was created 6,000 years ago. Creationism is NOT a major theory. No 
matter what percent of Americans or scientists believe in creationism, 
science does not discriminate. To be a major theory, it would have to be 
peer reviewed and explain our world with the evidence we have to view it 
with. If you believe, for instance, we should teach Creationism despite all 
evidence to the contrary, than it should stand to reason we should teach 
Last Thursdayism. If you are a logical person, then you should understand 
by now how this sort of logic will regress into absurdity because then we 
will have to teach kids the INFINITE amount of unfalsifiable theories that 
are possible. We have a limited amount of time to teach students. Do the 
math and the logic.

comments.text:
+Samael Scientific theories are the best explanations based on evidence. As 
scientific research focuses progresses, these theories are refined to be 
more accurate, so any potential problems are resolved.
Laws are not special, amazing concepts. They are mostly small, specific 
concepts, and they too can be wrong. Describing something as a law in 
science is really more of a shortcut, since understanding the entire 
concept is not always required for basic usage.



The idea that worms were created by rain was never a scientific theory, it 
was actually a concept developed by Aristotle. It's called spontaneous 
generation. It was debunked by actual science utilized the scientific 
method.


Evolution has been, and is continually being examined by scientists 
performing experiments. The overwhelming results have backed up the Theory 
of Evolution, and helped refine our understanding of it.

comments.text:
The problem here is with that definition of faith. I prefer to think of 
that concept as blind faith, and that does seem to suit a lot of people. 
Personally, I find blind faith to be really baffling. My own idea of the 
concept of faith is a lot different.  I like the analogy of abseiling. I'm 
scared of heights, to a quite severe degree, and I recall the instructor 
explaining that the ropes could hold the weight of the average car. I 
believed the guy had no reason to lie, and I saw a couple of friends go 
first, so I had faith that the rope was strong enough. Once I had the 
harness on, and the harness was connected to the main line and the safety 
line, my vertigo reduced significantly. I had faith that the rope would 
hold me, because of the evidence I had seen, and that faith was enough to 
get past a great deal of my fear. So that's my view of faith. Faith is the 
capacity to hold on to a position that you have reasoned out, based on 
however you reason things, in the face of the emotions raised by your 
current situation.
comments.author: Mark Love
